user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetLocalTime_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GetLocalTime_Impl(OS_time_t *time_struct)
{
    int             Status;
    int32           ReturnCode;
    struct timespec TimeSp;

    Status = clock_gettime(OSAL_GETTIME_SOURCE_CLOCK, &TimeSp);

    if (Status == 0)
    {
        *time_struct = OS_TimeAssembleFromNanoseconds(TimeSp.tv_sec, TimeSp.tv_nsec);
        ReturnCode   = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error calling clock_gettime: %s\n", strerror(errno));
        ReturnCode = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return ReturnCode;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GetLocalTime_Impl:
static inline OS_time_t OS_TimeAssembleFromNanoseconds(int64 seconds, uint32 nanoseconds)
{
    OS_time_t result;
    result.ticks = seconds * OS_TIME_TICKS_PER_SECOND;
    result.ticks += nanoseconds / OS_TIME_TICK_RESOLUTION_NS;
    return result;
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 forbids using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. I examined the provided code and additional definitions; there is no use of memcmp anywhere. The fragments present and why they do not require investigation:

- The call to clock_gettime (Status = clock_gettime(...)): This is a time-retrieval API, not a string comparison.
- Assignment via OS_TimeAssembleFromNanoseconds and the OS_TimeAssembleFromNanoseconds definition: This function performs integer arithmetic to build an OS_time_t (multiplication and division), with no string operations or comparisons.
- The OS_DEBUG invocation that passes strerror(errno): strerror returns a pointer to an error string but the code only passes it to a debug macro (which is defined as empty here). There is no comparison of strings, and no memcmp usage.
- Error handling and ReturnCode assignments: these are control-flow and integer assignments, not string comparisons.

No other functions or macros in the provided snippets perform string comparison operations, so there are no code fragments that match Rule 21.14 (using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings). Therefore I report no suspicious fragments.
